results.title: Elp: what's to be done
results.brief_description: Deals with the problem of noisy machinery in working environments, and the belated problems of silicosis and vascular spasms which are associated with working with pneumatic tools and equipment. Swedish industry is the scene of considerable research in this field.

results.title: Elliptical orbits
results.creator_credit: Kevin Smith, Educational Services and Norton Bloom
results.brief_description: Starting with an elliptic orbit (as of a satellite) and using Kepler’s law of areas, shows that the gravitational force on the satellite obeys an inverse square relation. The derivation is almost entirely geometric in nature.

results.title: Elizabethan stage: Henry V [study extract]
results.brief_description: The opening sequence of Olivier’s film version of “Henry V”. A remarkable recreation of Shakespeare’s London, showing the first part of the play as it may well have been produced originally on the stage of the Globe Theatre. Olivier’s treatment has been very free, and many amusing sidelights on the actors and audiences of Shakespeare’s day are included. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Robert Helpmann, Leslie Banks, Quentin Crisp.

results.title: Elizabethan express
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and Tony Thompson
results.brief_description: From King’s Cross Station, London, to Waverley Station, Edinburgh, is 393 miles. The Elizabethan - a summertime express - does this journey in six and a half hours non-stop - the longest daily non-stop run in the world to be timed at over 60 mph in 1954. This film is about one of those runs and the people behind the service.

results.title: Elizabethan England
results.creator_credit: Clement W. Bending, Gateway Film Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: Based on a horseback journey through towns, villages and open country, this film provides a central theme around which sequences are woven illustrating costumes, furniture, architecture, farming and other features of life during the first Elizabethan period. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clement W. Bending, Gateway Film Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley

results.title: Elizabeth: visual impairment
results.brief_description: From the “People you’d like to know” series this episode focuses on a young girl with impaired sight, showing how she has learnt to cope with her disability and adjusted to her surroundings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Elizabeth: the queen who shaped an age
results.creator_credit: John H Secondari Productions, Learning Corporation of America, John H. Secondari, Helen Jean Secondari and John Paddy Carstairs
results.brief_description: This dramatic recreation of the reign of Elizabeth I of England is a study of political power used for noble ends. Elizabeth inherited a troubled and divided country. A Protestant ruler in a predominantly Protestant country, she held out as long as she could against Parliament’s desire to pass anti-Catholic laws. When she discovered there was a plot against her life, Elizabeth signed the execution order against her cousin, Mary, Queen of Scots even though she feared this would divide England firmly into two camps - Protestants and Catholics. Elizabeth I forged a great nation - a military power second to none, a glorious home for the arts, commerce and exploration, and a symbol of the Renaissance belief in the worth of man. Cast: Frances Cuka as Elizabeth I. Filmed at Hever Castle, Kent, England. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Elizabeth Riddell
results.creator_credit: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Elizabeth Riddell came to Australia from New Zealand when she was eighteen. She recalls the community of artists and writers in Sydney in the 1930’s and her early experiences as a journalist. During the Second World War Riddell reported from North America and travelled through Europe. On her return to Australia, her long autobiographical poem was published. Riddell discusses the conflict between the demands of her career and her desire to write poetry. She speaks about the discipline of writing and the state of contemporary Australian literature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions

results.title: Elizabeth R.
results.brief_description: Glenda Jackson received world-wide acclaim for her brilliant portrayal of Queen Elizabeth the Ist. The series begins just prior to Elizabeth’s ascension to the throne and continues to her death in 1603. The episodes deal with historical events such as the Armada, Mary Queen of Scots, the beheading of Essex, the plight over the Succession and her decision to remain unmarried. The series is well scripted, costumed and has an excellent cast.
